In terms of social resonance, Vilis LapenieksÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ film The FishermanÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s Son has no equal. The film adaptation of Vilis LÃ„ï¿½cisÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ popular novel was a national blockbuster and created such excitement that at its premiere on 2 January, 1940, the public at the Splendid Palace broke down the theatreÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s doors. Deemed a Ã¢â‚¬Å“relic of bourgeois LatviaÃ¢â‚¬ï¿½, it was hidden during the Soviet years; when independence was regained, the film was once again up on the screen and became a symbol of the youth of the free Latvia. Slightly naive, fresh as a sea breeze, heartfelt and as real as a child of nature Ã¢â‚¬â€œ LatviaÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s first feature film.

Oskars lives in a typical sea-side village, but wants to break free of his fatherÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s rule and the old ways Ã¢â‚¬â€œ he dreams of new, large nets, an ice-cellar, and the fishermenÃ¢â‚¬â„¢s independence from the fish wholesaler. At first, no one wants to believe in OskarsÃ¢â‚¬â„¢ plans, except for happy-go-lucky Fredis. With the help of Fredis, Oskars builds a new fish trap, gaining admiration from even the old fishermen.
